case_vignette: a 6-year-old male with past medical history of aortic root dilation presents for evaluation of loose skin that was noticed at birth but has progressively worsened. family members have noticed the patient's skin is saggy but thought it may be related to overeating. the patient's mother reports other family members may have similar skin. physical examination reveals loose, sagging skin of the cheeks, neck, axilla, thighs. a punch biopsy demonstrates loss of elastic fibers. arm span width to body height ratio is within normal limits.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
Hello! I've noticed that my skin is very loose and saggy, especially on my cheeks, neck, underarms, and thighs.
How old are you?
I am 6 years old.
Do you have any other symptoms, such as muscle weakness or difficulty swallowing?
No, I don't have muscle weakness or difficulty swallowing.
Have other family members experienced similar skin or health problems?
Yes, my mother mentioned that other family members may have similar skin issues.
Has there been any recent weight loss associated with the sagging skin?
No, there hasn't been any recent weight loss associated with the sagging skin.
Final Diagnosis: Cutis Laxa
